reviewText: An exploration visits mysterious Tibet. The Englishmen are searching for a rare flower that only grows in Tibet. The natives are afraid to visit a valley from which no man has ever returned, it is said to be inhabited by demons. A missionary warns them against this, but they press on for their quest. A strange animal attacks one, but is driven off. The plant is harvested and returned to London (it only blooms under moonlight). Wilfred is obsessed since his return. They have strange plants in that museum, they eat insects. Dr. Yogami of the University of Carpathia visits, he too is a student of plants (like that moon flower). Can this flower be an antidote to werewolfery? A pet dog is suddenly upset, then Dr. Yogami enters. The film shows a camera that shows anyone who visits the laboratory (the latest in high technology). An old book explains why a human must be killed by a werewolf each night - to be able to return to human form.Night transforms Wilfred into a werewolf before your eyes! He then leaves to prowl the streets. There is an attempt on Miss Edie, but her guests think she was drunk. The next victim doesn't escape. Wilfred and Lisa are invited for a moonlight ride. Wilfred won't go, but Lisa is stubborn. There are some jokes sprinkled to carry the plot along. Wilfred seeks a rented room for isolation (like "The Invisible Man"). The film shows another transformation of Wilfred to Werewolf. Then another victim. Dr. Yogami visits Scotland Yard to warn about werewolves, but they don't believe him. [Note how people don't want to accept warnings about some future problem?] Wilfred visits a place where he can be locked up. But there is another transformation and another attack on a woman. The police suspect Wilfred, but can't find him. Dr. Yogami visits the laboratory to steal the last flowers, denying the antidote to Wilfred. Now Wilfred goes to attack Lisa, wandering in the moonlight. But the police arrive and fire a bullet to end this tragedy (like "The Invisible Man"). There will be a cover-up of the facts. Nobody will believe the story of a werewolf! Would you?This film resulted in many sequels which continued until this story was played out. The story can be seen as a parable about addiction to a drug that men will kill for. Or a romance where an unhappy wife's husband conveniently dies after an old love returns. This is an interesting story as long as you don't question the situation. The later Hollywood version created a new reality about werewolves, silver bullets, full moons, etc. so they became part of popular culture. [Warner Oland's acting style is similar to his "Charlie Chan" films.]

reviewText: Warner Oland is simply wonderful as the mysterious Dr. Yogamiand Henry Hull plays the other unfortunate victim of lycanthropy withperfection.This was Universal's first attempt at the werewolf story, and it is too bad that this film is attacked by many critics.The old London, foggy atmosphere is erie setting,music(which was used in other Universal films of the period) is good, set pieces are beautiful, plot is interesting(remember"2 buds from the marafasia lupina will save 2 souls tonight......").Early transformation scene is interesting as Hull becomes harrier as he walks by each wall.Beautiful Valerie Hobson is a good Universal Scream Queen.There is even a scene involving 2 gin-swilling old ladies that is reminiscent of the Bride of Frankenstein(I swear I thought one of those old ladies was Una O'Connor!).One complaint I have is what was that weird final shot of that old bi-plane flying with the triumphant music blaring in the background? Highly recommend this film!

reviewText: What can I say ?. -A werewolf movie starring one of my favorite actors; Henry Hull, can't be all that bad. In fact, this is a very good little Horror film. Alright, so Hull may not be a charmer in this one, but who  said only likeable people can become werewolfs ?. Just sit back, and enjoy  the fun; there's lots of it: Hull renting a room as "the lonliest  person in the world", a not-too-hairy Hull stalking the neighbourhood  at night, the Tibet-attack that you can't see, and many unfunny old ladies.  This is a true gem, and so much better than the ones with Chaney-junior.  I'm tired of reading negative things about Hull; not just regarding this  movie, but in general. He had a very unique style, and if he hadn't stopped  with Horror, he would've had a huge cult-following today. Instead he went  and dug his own "supporting-character-grave", with countless  Westerns, dramas, and Gangster-flicks. -Good movies, but they didn't make  him a star, or a household name. "Horror" could have.
summary: So much better than its reputation.

reviewText: Mention a werewolf, and you immediately think of the afflicted Larry Talbot played by Lon Chaney, Jr., in the classic monster films of the 1940s.  Not only was Chaney not the first Wolf Man, he was not even Universal's first Wolf Man - that distinction goes to Henry Hull, who played a werewolf in Universal's 1935 classic Werewolf of London.  This film, residing as it does in the shadows of Chaney's memorable werewolf films, is often overlooked; it is also unduly dismissed by some reviewers and horror fans.  This is a much different type of movie than 1941's The Wolf Man, but it is really quite an enjoyable viewing experience.Forget gypsies, wolf bane, pentagrams on the hands of victims, and the other werewolf staples Curt Siodmak put into his script of The Wolf Man.  In Werewolf of London, botanist Wilfred Glendon (Hull) sees his troubles begin in - of all places - Tibet, where he traveled in search of a very special flower, the "Marifasa Lupina."  This particular flower grows only in Tibet, and it blooms only in moonlight.  He gets his flower, but he also gets a nasty bite from a werewolf for his troubles.  Back home in London, he is hard at work trying to get the flower to bloom under artificial moonlight - apparently, it would make for some sort of major scientific discovery, but the flower takes on new meaning after a certain Dr. Yogami (Warner Oland) pays him a visit and expresses his own interest in the plant.  Glendon doesn't believe Yogami's wild tales about werewolves - not until, that is, he turns into one that very night.This isn't your ordinary werewolf.  After his transformation, Glendon goes looking for a bloom of the flower (which, while not a cure for his affliction, would prevent him from killing those he loves the most) and then, before heading out into the streets, stops to put on his coat, hat, and scarf; he is relatively conscious of what he is doing, although he is powerless to stop the blood rage pumping through his veins.  The actual transformations, several of which are shown in the film, are rather impressive for such an early film.  He's not overly hairy, but there is a definite look of evil intelligence in his eyes.Of course, you have to have a leading lady in this type of film, and that role is filled quite well by the lovely Valerie Hobson (1935 was quite a year for Hobson, as she played Dr. Frankenstein's wife in Bride of Frankenstein as well as a werewolf's wife here in Werewolf of London).  Warner Oland gives a memorable performance as Yogami, but I must lavish special attention on three older ladies.  Spring Byington is quite a hoot as Glendon's rich lush of an aunt, but Ethel Griffies and Zeffie Tilbury absolutely steal the show as Mrs. Whack and Mrs. Moncaster.  These two ladies deliver a comic tour de force as inebriated best friends who take a great interest in Glendon when he comes asking to rent a room from one of them.  Back in the old days, movie studios (or more likely, censors) didn't think audiences could withstand all of the frights and chills of a harmless monster movie like this without a few stiff doses of comedy thrown in to the mix - oftentimes, such comic relief failed miserably, but here it is spot on indeed.Despite the fact that Glendon is as unsympathetic a character as you can find (the antithesis of Lon Chaney, Jr.'s Larry Talbot), I have to give this movie five stars.  The plot has a level of complexity to it that adds to its impact, the makeup and special effects are quite impressive, and it has that unidentifiable something that a good horror movie has to have to succeed.  Werewolf of London isn't as entertaining as Universal's Wolf Man films of the 1940s, but it is definitely worth watching.
summary: Universal's first werewolf film is too often overlooked
Title: N/A

reviewText: 1935's "Werewolf of London" was Universal Pictures' first (pre-Lon Chaney) effort to bring the werewolf monster to the big screen.  This movie lacks some of the trappings of the traditional werewolf mythology but is a worthwhile and chillingly well-done horror movie on its own.A London botanist, Dr. Wilfred Glendon (played with single-minded scientific certitude by Henry Hull) neglects his young wife in order to travel to Tibet in search of a rare flower that legendarily blooms only in moonlight.  Glendon finds his flower, but only after surviving an attack by a mysterious creature.Back in London, Glendon is visited by another scientist, a Dr. Yogami (played with perfect foreboding by Warner Oland of the Charlie Chan movies).  Yogami enigmatically claims to have met Glendon in Tibet and informs him of the special properties of his exotic flower.  The flower apparently has mitigating effects on the behavior of werewolves.  Yogami further hints that a recent spate of killings in London have been committed by two werewolves.  Glendon reacts with proper scientific skepticism to this strange account, until the arrival of the next full moon causes his involuntary transformation into a werewolf. Thus begins a path of destruction that will tear through London to Dr. Glendon's own doorstep as he tries frantically to find a cure.This 1935 black and white movie has lots of nice atmospherics, including foggy London streets, a half-lit laboratory, and a very credible transformation sequence, as Glendon thrashes into something resembling Mr. Hyde with fangs.  Henry Hull is very effective as the single-minded scientist who becomes increasingly horrified by his inability to stave off either the transformation or the murderous behavior that follows. Valerie Hobson has a nice turn as Glendon's patient but doomed wife Lisa.This movie is highly recommended to fans of the horror genre looking for an early but well-done werewolf movie.
summary: The Wolfman by way of Mr. Hyde...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although it was filmed during the first and memorable cycles of Universal horror films, WEREWOLF OF LONDON is hardly in the same league with DRACULA, FRANKENSTEIN, or THE BLACK CAT.  Simply put, it lacks imagination.The story opens with botanist Dr. Wilfred Glendon (Henry Hull) in search of a rare flowering plant in the wilds of Tibet--but although he secures a specimen, Glendon is bitten by a werewolf in the process.  Once more returned to his wife Lisa (Valerie Hobson) in London, Glendon is approached by Dr. Yogami (Warner Oland), who makes somewhat cryptic comments about the Tibet, the flower, and werewolves.  It soon transpires that Yogami is the werewolf that attacked Glendon in Tibet and that the flower is the only antidote.  Yogami steals the flowers, leaving Glendon to transform into a ravening beast that is driven to kill his own wife.The story itself is entertaining and Jack Pierce's make-up effects are quite good.  Warner Oland walks away with the acting honors and Spring Byington is not far behind.  But the rest of the cast is remarkably uninspired.  Henry Hull was a noted stage actor, but he simply did not play well on the screen.  In WEREWOLF OF LONDON he seems unduly stiff in some scenes and excessively ripe in others.  Valerie Hobson was a pleasant performer, but she is not particularly memorable here; Lester Matthews is utterly non-descript; and Ethel Griffies and Zeffie Tilbury quickly wear out their welcome in the roles of competing (and besotted) boarding house landladies.  Diector Stuart Walker's pacing seems clumsy and irregular, there is nothing interesting in the editing or designs.  The movie isn't bad enough to be truly bad, but neither is it good enough to be truly good--and it is mightily overshadowed by the later Lon Chaney Jr. film THE WOLF MAN.  Best left to hardcore fans of Universal Horror.GFT, Amazon Reviewer
summary: So-So Universal Horror, Best Left To Hardcore Fans

reviewText: An atmospheric rarity from the Universal film vault, "Werewolf of London" stars Henry Hull as a botanist who is bitten by a bizarre animal while searching for the elusive Marifasa flower in the desolate mountains of Tibet. When he returns to London and pretty wife Valerie Hobson, Hull begins to have unearthly experiences to which the mysterious Dr. Yogami (played strongly by the legendary Warner Oland) seems to have the only improbable answers. This was Universal's first foray in werewolf territory, and today isn't nearly as well remembered as the later "The Wolfman" starring Lon Chaney. They're both good films, but I prefer "Werewolf of London." The London of this movie is a veritable urban jungle, a giant mist-shrouded haunted maze where the werewolf stalks his prey like the legendary Minotaur. The cast is excellent, and delivers highly believable and dramatic performances, despite the fact (or perhaps because of the fact) that none of the usual Universal stalwarts are present. The script is taut and more realistic than many later werewolf stories, and the special effects are outstanding considering the time period. Hull's transformation scenes are handled much more fluidly here than similar moments in "The Wolfman," and Hull's werewolf is unique in that it retains some latent human intelligence--it not only speaks, but puts on a disguise before venturing out in search of unsuspecting prey. The werewolf attacks are quite fierce, perhaps the most aggressive monster scenes of any of Universal's earliest ventures. Needless to say, Hull's new persona plays havoc with his personal life, and before long his wife is turning to old friend Lester Matthews for comfort. Of course, this turn of events merely exaggerates Hull's new animal instincts. Astutely and delicately handled, this romantic subplot adds a strong element of human pathos to this supernatural thriller. The great universal "scary movies" were never intended to be truly horrifying, even in their day, so fans of modern splatter-films won't find what they're looking for here. But for lovers of classic mystery and fantasy, "The Werewolf of London" is a rare treat.

reviewText: Werewolf of London is one hour and fifteen minuets long and was released on May 13, 1935. Werewolf of London is nothing like the Wolf Man. First of all this Werewolf has a conscience and knows what he is doing, whereas the Wolf Man just goes out and kills and does not remember a thing the next day. Also the make-up is more tone down where you see more facial features and less wolf features. This is because Henry Hull (the star of the movie) refused to sit down for long hours to apply make-up. Jack Pierce wanted to do something more similar to that of the Wolf Man movie. Others that are different; you need the blossom from the mariphasa plant to temporarily prevent the transformation into a werewolf, no silver bullet is required to kill the werewolf and you don't hear that famous phrase throughout the movie:Even a man who is pure in heartand says his prayers by nightmay become a wolf when the wolfbane bloomsand the autumn moon is bright.The story begins in Tibet where Dr. Wilfred Glendon and a friend are looking for the rare mariphasa plant, which only blooms at moonlight. Dr. Glendon finds the plant, but is attack by a werewolf. The werewolf bites Dr. Glendon in the arm during the struggle. Back home, with the plant in his possession, he begins to study the mariphasa plant. One night while studying the mariphasa plant under a moon lamp, his hand begins to change. Dr. Glendon administers some of the serum from the plant and the hand is restored. It is later found out that it is only a temporary cure as told by Dr. Yogami (Warner Oland). Dr. Yogami is also the other werewolf that attacked him in Tibet. Dr. Glendon tries to lock himself away so he cannot kill anyone until the blossom has re-grown. Dr. Glendon cannot control his transformation and begins killing. The story ends with Dr. Glendon killing Dr. Yogami because he has stolen the treatment and brought this curse on him. Dr. Glendon is killed by Sir Thomas Forsythe because the werewolf was attacking Lisa, Dr. Glendon's wife. In the end we see the werewolf transform back into Dr. Wilfred Glendon. During the transformation, he starts looking like a grown up Eddie Munster. Also Dr. Wilfred Glendon is killed with a regular bullet and not a silver one. This movie gets a B- for the water down werewolf design.
summary: Not as good as the Wolf Man
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an interesting werewolf story which plays more like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. Henry Hull's werewolf is no match for Lon Chaney Jr.'s but, it's not his fault. At the time they made this film, Universal was apprehensive about showing a wolfman that was "too Hairy" and the actual wolfman transformation. I have read that Jack Pierce had designed a more elaborate make-up but the studio opted against it. The folklore is not the same as the 1941 classic either and this film takes a more scientific approach. It's a fun film filled with great sets, atmosphere and an early Jack Pierce make-up. I am reviewing this film here because it is available on DVD on the Wolfman Legacy Collection with 3 other werewolf related films and a some interesting extras.
summary: WEREWOLF OF LONDON OR.....DR. JEKYLL  AND MR. WOLFMAN!

reviewText: The first sound werewolf movie & oddly enough, one of the least celebrated in Universal's library of classic horror films, largely overshadowed by a later vehicle title "The Wolf Man" that would elevate the werewolf to classic monster status.But that's not to say "Werewolf of London" is a bad film, far from it. A very strong supporting cast, some good humor & some very effective werewolf makeup make for a very good film.The only thing that may be holding WOL back is the lead played by Henry Hull, who is far from the sympathetic figure portrayed by Lon Chaney in the 1940s. But, whatever charm Hull may lack, Warner Oland makes up for in spades with his performance as Dr. Yogami.Henry Hull & his London Werewolf may forever linger in Chaney's shadow, but that shouldn't stop anyone who is a lover of classic horror from giving this a view or two. 4 1/2 stars

reviewText: Released in 1935, this is the first classic werewolf film and a great one at that. Having turned down an original script entitled "The Wolfman", Karloff passed on this golden opportunity, a decision that I'm sure he would later regret. The honors went instead to noted stage actor Henry Hull, who would also appear in Hitchcock's classic "Lifeboat". Comparisons, of course, are made to Universal's later and more successful, "The Wolfman". However, this great film is filled with enough pathos and scares that it stands very well on it's own. With make-up by Universal's master craftsman Jack Pierce, Hull along with a first rate supporting cast, including Warner Orland, who would later go on to become the screen's most popular "Charlie Chan", deliver a film that between thrills, plays like a greek tragedy. Hull's werewolf is a terrifying creature indeed, and is most accurately described in the film itself: "...a werewolf is neither man nor wolf, but a satanic creature possessing the worst characteristics of both". This film is a MUST SEE for horror film fans in general, and werewolf buffs in particular. A great ride!-Rick

reviewText: ...there was the "Werewolf of London," staring Henry Hull and Valerie Hobson, who is better known for her role as Elizabeth in "Bride of Frankenstein."Although George Waggner's "The Wolf Man" seems to always steel all the credit as the definative classic werewolf film, "Werewolf of London" is an underrated jem and the origional werewolf film and a true classic. Although the plot is very "Frankenstein" like, it has a great cast, great looking werewolf for a first time ever, great atmosphere, great music, and great lighting.All in all, though "The Wolf Man" gets all the credit, "Werewolf of London" is just as good and worth the watch.
summary: Before the American Werewolf in London...

reviewText: Suspenseful early foray into the "werewolf" world by the purveyors of classic monsters, Universal Studios.  Dr. Wilfred Glendon  (Henry Hull), a dedicated but rather stuffy botanist, travels to Tibet in  search of a rare species of "moon flower."  During a frightening  encounter in a forbidden valley under a bright full moon, Glendon is  attacked by a furry, man-like creature.  After he returns to London,  Glendon discovers he may be inflicted by "lycanthrophobia."  He  tries to dismiss the warning from the cryptic Dr. Yogami by laughing it off  as a "medieval unpleasantness."  When a mad killer starts  prowling London slums, Glendon draws some grim conclusions.This movie is  occasionally disparaged by reviewers of classic horror films.  The arguably  unsympathetic portrayal of the title character by Henry Hull is cited as  the primary problem.  Regardless of one's opinion of Hull's performance,  dismissing the entire film is a mistake.The werewolf makeup is very  scary.  Dr. Yogami asserts that a werewolf is neither man nor wolf but a  satanic creature inflicted with the worst qualities of both. The horrifying  makeup suggests this peculiar distinction nicely.  This werewolf is less  furry than some versions, but more fiendish.  Pointed ears, a V-shaped  forelock in the center of the forehead, elongated canine teeth, and a  distinctive pompadour that is definitely not human adds to the terror.  The  creature's lonely isolation between the human and animal world is visually  emphasized.The spooky atmosphere of the foggy London night is effective.  There is great comic relief via two slightly inebriated old women called  Mrs. Moncaster and Mrs. Whack, the Lucy and Ethel of classic horror films.  These two comic characters have been dismissed as an inadequate attempt to  emulate the dark humor of the marvelous James Whale.  In this reviewer's  opinion, they hilariously supply the needed comic relief.  Warner Oland,  who some viewers will recall as "Charlie Chan," is appropriately  tragic as Dr. Yogami.  He is able to fill in the blanks from personal  experience of Glendon's "singularly single" problem. The  "moon flower" is not a cure, but rather a temporary antidote to  sooth lost souls howling in the night.  The two men agressively vie for the  matured flower growing in Dr. Glendon's lab, and the room reeks of  metamorphosis and murder.This film doesn't have the public stature of  such horror classics as "Bride of Frankenstein" or Lon Chaney,  JR's "The Wolfman."  Regardless, this movie is a perennial  favorite that should be on every collector's classic horror film shelf.  Enjoy the ride.  ;-)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Universal's 1935 precursor to "The Wolf Man" has some historic interest, but remains among the studio's dullest horror films. Originally intended as a Karloff-Lugosi vehicle, "Werewolf of London" is worth a look for Jack Pierce's influential makeup. Character actor Henry Hull delivers a strangely unsympathetic performance in the title role - little helped by Stuart Walker's flat direction. The lack of atmospheric set-pieces make the 75-minute running time seem like an eternity. "Werewolf of London" truly needed Boris and Bela's potent star power.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hollywood and England's Hammer studios have produced some very famous werewolf horror movies over the years and when this subgenre is mentioned most peoples thoughts automatically recall 1941's classic horror masterpiece "The Wolf Man". Starring a tragic Lon Chaney that film is a horror classic and is always credited with putting werewolf's on the horror map so to speak. However as great a masterpiece as that effort is it was not the first film on this theme that Universal Studios had produced. That honour goes to this 1935 effort "Werewolf of London", and while sadly it tends to be a film largely forgotten nowadays it is a most polished and at times quite frightening horror effort. For this early time "Werewolf of London" displays startlingly vivid special effects in it's werewolf transformation scenes which paved the way for the better known equivalents in later Universal efforts. Hampered some say by an unlikeable leading man in Henry Hull who lacks the tragic qualities of Lon Chaney's anguished Larry Talbot in "The Wolf Man",I still feel it is an interesting performance that simply takes a different slant on the story of a man afflicted with the curse of "lycanthrophobia"."Werwolf of London", begins in the eerie shadows of a canyon in far off Tibet where gifted botanist Dr. Wilfred Glendon (Henry Hull), has trekked to in search of the extremely rare Marisfasa flower which only grows in remote regions of Tibet and only blooms during the full moon. Warned by a travelling holy man about the evil devils that lurk in the valley who have taken the lives of all who have entered the valley before him Dr. Glendon goes on. However just after discovering the rare flower he is viciously attacked by a strange furred creature that inflicts a severe bit on his arm. Returning to London Dr. Glendon continues his obsessive research into the powerful qualities of the rare flower to the detriment of his marriage with neglected wife Lisa (Valerie Hobson). He is visited by a strange gentlemen by the name of Dr. Yogami (Warner Oland), who is from the University of Carpathia and informs Dr. Glendon of another value of this rare flower in that it is an antidote to lycanthrobia, or the bite of a werewolf. Dr. Yogami is not all that he seems to first be and is hiding a terrible secret which makes him need the blooms of the Maraphasa for himself. Meanwhile the first full moon arrives and Dr. Glendon finds that Dr. Orgami's persistance in trying to get the flowers from him is the least of his worries as he finds himself turning into a savage hairy beast or werewolf after which he wanders the foggy streets of London killing innocent victims. Warned by Yogami that the werewolf kills the one thing it loves, Dr. Glendon begins stalking his wife Lisa who has turned for companionship and protection to childhood sweetheart Cpt. Paul Ames (Lester Matthews). The killings however continue and in a fight over the now blooming plant that Dr. Glendon has in his lab Dr. Yogami is killed. Trying to isolate himself so that he wont cause anymore deaths Glendon goes to the family country house however Lisa and Paul have travelled there as well and Glendon then attacks Lisa. Barracaded in the house Glendon breaks in and tries to finish off Lisa however the Scotland Yard Detectives arrive just in time and shoot Glendon who dies, and before everyone's horrified eyes slowly transforms back into his human form.For 1935 the transformation scenes that turn Henry Hull into a vicious werewolf are quite startling and it is a mystery why the makeup here is not as acclaimed as that used on Lon Chaney in 1941's "The Wolf Man". It took an amazing four hours for Hull to be transformed into the werewolf courtesy of Jack Pierce's magic makeup genius and the scenes where the transformations take place are remarkably smooth. Bacause Henry Hull plays the character of Dr. Glendon as a less sympathetic character than Lon Chaney's later Larry Talbot he perhaps engages the audience in his plight less however he is still highly effective in the role and his werewolf seems to possess an interesting element of intelligence in that it can create disguises and dress differently when it is on the hunt for victims. His scenes when he is prowling through London attacking people have a raw viciousness about them that keeps your attention. Warner Oland as the mysterious Dr. Yogami is still best known for his famous Charlie Chan film series and is at his sinister best here as the man trying to steal Glendon's antidote. All his scenes have a certain eerie quality to them that seems to fill the viewer with a sense of unease about his real intentions. As the romantic heroine Valerie Hobson who is still remembered for playing Elizabeth in the classic "Bride of Frankenstein", is adequate for what the role calls for including the ability to scream. She is however largely overshadowed by the other main female character of Aunt Ettie played by Spring Byington in the type of delightfully daffy performance which became her speciality. Her repeated inability to pronounce Dr. Orgami's name and her inability to hold her liquer make for some delightful light moments among the seriousness of the rest of the story. As befitted a Carl Laemmle Universal Studios release, "Werewolf of London", seems to deny its small budget by an incredibly atmosheric recreation of a foggy London and a mysterious landscape in Tibet that are the ideal backdrop for the story as it unfolds.Often overshadowed by its illustrious successor "The Wolf Man", this earlier production deserves to be better remembered and certainly as the first full fledged werewolf movie warrants a treasured place in any early horror collectors film library. Rich in atmosphere and quite startling in its makeup and attack scenes it makes for most enjoyable viewing and shows once again what the early 1930's film makers working with small budgets and none of the modern special effects wizardry available today,  were capable of achieving. Make "Werewolf of London", part of your Universal Studios Classic Monster collection soon and see for yourself the amazing beginning of the whole werewolf/wolfman series of horror films.
summary: Atmospheric First Werewolf Movie That Is Often Overlooked

reviewText: Living in Australia it has always been difficult to view the 'obscure classics' but in todays times it is only a click of your mouse button. I for one feel priveliged to have viewed this movie.The tension is from the start with the errie backdrop and the certainty of our poor hero's fate. The special effects of the time ensure the enjoyment of the viewer, that is to say we must rely on the actors ability to convince us of the horror and torment he is going through. The movie flows from scene to scene and by the time the credits roll you are still transfixed to the screen totally enthralled by what you have seen.If you are interested in the Universal classics this is definately one for your collection. You will not be disapointed.
